column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=South American Community of Nations announced at Third South American Summit
#Text=December 2004
#Text=South
#Text=American nations began the creation of an international economic and legislative bloc by a declaration made at the Third South American Summit on 8 December .
#Text=Named the South American Community of Nations , the organization is a step toward greater coordination among South American states .

#Text=Two existing South American trade blocs , the Andean Community ( Comunidad Andina ) and the Southern Common Market ( Mercado Común del Sur , or Mercosur ) , have been combined and three previously uninvolved states included to create the community .
#Text=The summit , held between 7-9 December at Cusco and Ayacucho in Peru , was attended by heads of state from Bolivia , Brazil , Chile , Colombia , Guyana , Peru , Suriname , and Venezuela .
#Text=Foreign ministers attended for Argentina , Ecuador , Paraguay , and Uruguay .
#Text=The summit was convened principally to sign the two-page Preamble to the Foundation Act of the South American Union on the second day of the summit .
#Text=Although the Bolivian and Colombian presidents attended the summit , they did not attend the signing ceremony , this instead being done by representatives .
#Text=Central American states Mexico and Panama attended the ceremony as observers .
#Text=The locations for the summit were chosen for their historical significance and their association with events that reflect well on South America .
#Text=Cusco was the ancient capital of the advanced civilization of the Incas .
#Text=Ayachucho was the site of an 1824 decisive victory against Spanish troops by the South American independence movement headed by Simón Bolívar .
#Text=The First and Second South American Summits were held at Brasília , Brazil in September 2000 and Guayaquil , Ecuador in July 2002 .
#Text=The community will include every state in South America with the exception of French Guiana , itself a territory of France .
#Text=Bolivia , Colombia , Ecuador , Peru , and Venezuela join SACN from the Andean Community , a trade bloc established in 1969 .
#Text=From the more recent ( 1991 ) Mercosur comes Argentina , Brazil , Paraguay , and Uruguay .
#Text=Guyana , Suriname , two small northeastern countries which had previously not participated in a South American trade bloc , will not immediately join the community .
#Text=Chile will additionally join ; it has , however , been cautious .
#Text=SACN is a more ambitious union than the previous Andean Community and Mercosur .
#Text=It has been established to be more than a trade union .
#Text=The " ultimate goal , which can hopefully be reached , in time , is the United States of South America , " explains Secretary General of the Andean Community Wagner .
#Text=A common currency , tariff-free common market , and regional parliament are all proposed in the Cusco declaration .
#Text=Many disputes exist between South American nations that may be issues in advancing SACN .
#Text=The principal force behind SACN has been Brazil .
#Text=The First South American Summit was held in Brazil through the efforts of Brazilian President Fernando Henrique Cardoso .
#Text=Chile has been an associate member of Mercosur since 1996 .
#Text=It was a member of the Andean Community from its inception in 1969 , but withdrew six years later when ruled by General Augusto Pinochet .

#Text=With 70 % of its GDP attributed to foreign trade , Chile has traditionally favored relations with the United States or the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum over South American agreements .
#Text=SACN 's short-term political and economic effects may be limited .
#Text=The elimination of all trade tariffs has long been a goal of both the Andean Community and Mercosur , but has had little success .
#Text=However , 32 construction projects were approved at the summit .
#Text=Worth US$4.3bn over five years , the projects focus on improving regional infrastructure .
#Text=The largest is a US$700m road highway that will link Brazil and Peru across the Andes mountains .
#Text=" These are anchor projects that will be carried out over five years , " said Wagner .

#Text=" They were chosen because they do not serve merely as corridors between countries and zones , but also as a means of promoting development in border regions , which have traditionally been the poorest and most marginalised in our countries .
